top_positive.sent: Funded Status The following table provides a reconciliation of benefit obligations, plan assets and net (unfunded) funded status of our qualified defined benefit pension plans and our retiree medical and life insurance plans (in millions): Qualified Defined Benefit Pension Plans Retiree Medical and Life Insurance Plans 2023 2022 2023 2022 Change in benefit obligation Beginning balance (a) $ 28,698 $ 43,447 $ 1,359 $ 1,839 Service cost 65 87 5 9 Interest cost 1,459 1,289 68 49 Actuarial losses (gains) (b) 731 ( 10,270 ) 27 ( 396 ) Settlements (c) ( 414 ) ( 4,309 ) — — Plan amendments 6 186 1 1 Benefits paid ( 1,586 ) ( 1,732 ) ( 192 ) ( 207 ) Medicare Part D subsidy — — 1 3 Participants’ contributions — — 59 61 Ending balance (a) $ 28,959 $ 28,698 $ 1,328 $ 1,359 Change in plan assets Beginning balance at fair value $ 23,228 $ 35,192 $ 1,656 $ 2,169 Actual return on plan assets (d) 1,572 ( 5,923 ) 190 ( 381 ) Settlements (c) ( 414 ) ( 4,309 ) — — Benefits paid ( 1,586 ) ( 1,732 ) ( 192 ) ( 207 ) Company contributions — — 1 11 Medicare Part D subsidy — — 1 3 Participants’ contributions — — 59 61 Ending balance at fair value $ 22,800 $ 23,228 $ 1,715 $ 1,656 (Unfunded) funded status of the plans $ ( 6,159 ) $ ( 5,470 ) $ 387 $ 297 (a) Benefit obligation balances represent the projected benefit obligation for our qualified defined benefit pension plans, which is approximately equal to accumulated benefit obligation, and accumulated benefit obligation for our retiree medical and life insurance plans.

Note 2 – Earnings Per Share The weighted average number of shares outstanding used to compute earnings per common share were as follows (in millions): 2023 2022 2021 Weighted average common shares outstanding for basic computations 250.3 263.7 276.4 Weighted average dilutive effect of equity awards 0.9 0.9 1.0 Weighted average common shares outstanding for diluted computations 251.2 264.6 277.4 We compute basic and diluted earnings per common share by dividing net earnings by the respective weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the periods presented.

Note 2 – Earnings Per Share The weighted average number of shares outstanding used to compute earnings per common share were as follows (in millions): 2023 2022 2021 Weighted average common shares outstanding for basic computations 250.3 263.7 276.4 Weighted average dilutive effect of equity awards 0.9 0.9 1.0 Weighted average common shares outstanding for diluted computations 251.2 264.6 277.4 We compute basic and diluted earnings per common share by dividing net earnings by the respective weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the periods presented.

top_negative.sent: Products and services we provide to customers also carry cybersecurity risks, including risks that they could be breached or fail to detect, prevent or combat attacks, which could result in losses to our customers and claims against us, and could harm our relationships with our customers and financial results.

In addition to cybersecurity threats, we face threats to the security of our facilities and employees from terrorist acts, sabotage or other disruptions, any of which could adversely affect our business.

Given the persistence, sophistication, volume and novelty of threats we face, we may not be successful in preventing or mitigating an attack that could have a material adverse effect on us and the costs related to cyber or other security threats or disruptions may not be fully insured or indemnified by other means.

forward_snippets: We are engaged in significant classified development programs and pending successful achievement of the objectives within those programs, we expect to begin the transition from development to production over the next few years.

We invest substantially in our people to ensure that our workforce has the technical skills necessary to succeed, and we expect to continue to invest internally in innovative technologies that address rapidly evolving mission requirements for our customers.
We continue to explore technology advancement and insertion into our existing aircraft.

We also are involved in numerous network-enabled activities that allow separate systems to work together to increase effectiveness and we continue to invest in new technologies to maintain and enhance competitiveness in military aircraft design, development and production.

We are engaged in significant classified development programs and pending successful achievement of the objectives within those programs, we expect to begin the transition from development to production over the next few years.
